Ice Trae melted in this one, missing all six from deep and getting torched by Ryan Arcidiacono. Young continues to dominate the rock as one of the leaders in time of possession, his usage rate is better than expected and the Hawks are flying with an NBA-high 108.6 pace.

He might have a few more minutes coming his way, as Moe Harkless left knee flared up on him again and he wasnt able to return. Turner has been quiet up to this point with 9.8 points, 5.3 assists, 3.5 rebounds and 1.0 steals with no triples entering Saturdays game, and its unlikely that Harkless latest setback will catapult Turner into standard-league relevance.

Apparently the heckling fan from Thursday is still in the back of Lillard's head. That's his 18th career game with 40+ points which moves him past Clyde Drexler for most in Trail Blazers history. He's got the Western Conference Player of the Week Award locked up as he's coming off a 41-point game vs. Orlando, and we're still feeling confident about calling him a top-10 fantasy asset the rest of the way.

Last season was about as bad as it could get, but this year he's making up ground. Coach Lloyd Pierce has praised Bembry's ability to break down defenses, and it's reflected in the rotation with Bembry getting at least 27 minutes in three of the last four. He's not quite standard-league material yet, but that could change if the Hawks unload some guys.

It wasn't clear before the game whether or not Embiid would be limited by the ankle tweak he suffered in Friday's practice, but he removed all doubt once the game began. Embiid now has six consecutive double-doubles to start the season and has played 33+ minutes in each game. He'll have an injury scare every now and then, but he's a fantasy monster when he's available.

Simmons posted a shockingly-low assist total tonight, but that's probably because he took a season-high 20 shots. Despite only three assists, he's still averaging over seven per game thus far. It was nice to see him in attack mode from the jump, but the efficiency obviously needs to be better. Simmons might be asked to be in attack mode more often with Markelle Fultz able to run the offense, too. Keep rolling Simmons out there with confidence.

He kept the Hawks in this game with a team-high +18. Dedmon looked like himself in this game after his avulsion fracture kept him out of camp and the first week of the season. Bigs can be tough to come by and the Hawks don't have Alex Poythress (knee) now, so Dedmon is worth a long look for anyone needing a big man.
Giannis has been in and out for most of the game due to an early collision with Aaron Gordon. Hopefully we find out more information once the game concludes.

He had a 23.2 usage rate with Kevin Love (foot) sitting out another game and led the Cavaliers in points and shot attempts and was second to Cedi Osman in minutes. Hood was hitting just 38.6% of his shots before Saturday, but has scored in double digits in each game so far. Hood might be relevant for the foreseeable future because of the lack of talent in Cleveland.

It was like he was playing college kids with easy shots around the rim all night, and owning the paint on defense.  Gobert has been automatic with the ball, making 76.9% from the field with a respectable 71.9% from the line to get him to a 78.2 TS% on his 15.5 usage rate. He's also playing at a 105.0 pace, so this could be Gobert's best year yet.

He was 3-of-7 from the field with no turnovers. Love has missed two games in a row with foot soreness and the 0-6 Cavaliers will be patient with him, but we don't see a reason to pick up Dekker yet. Larry Nance looks like the big winner.

He needed this one after a putrid 21.9% from the field in his first four. Anyone who has owned Rubio in the past will tell you all about his dreadful starts over the last few years, but picked up speed down the home stretch like Seabiscuit. Rubio should hold mid-round value on the year and the extra pace could help his ceiling.

Cavaliers coach Ty Lue is on record saying he wants to get Smith more involved, but the front office wants him to focus on the younger guys. Its pretty obvious that Smith isnt going to be useful in fantasy leagues any time soon.

He played a total of six minutes across two appearances prior to Saturday, so hes still irrelevant in all fantasy leagues. As bad as Cleveland has been, this could set Nwaba up for more run as we get closer to the new year.

That's a season-high in points and rebounds and he's now played 20+ minutes in three straight. Kevin Love (foot) is already banged, the Cavs are winless and have very little talent, so all signs point to Nance becoming one of Cleveland's top fantasy assets going forward. He should be owned in standard leagues and should have some starts coming his way.

He has been outstanding against two good teams, and he even gave Jrue Holiday the business all game. Mitchell dropped 38 points in Houston and he's back on track with efficiency, and he's handed out 13 dimes to just four turnovers in those two wins. Mitchell should lead the Jazz in scoring as he puts up early-round value in fantasy.

We can't overreact here, as Tyreke Evans (personal) did not suit up. His minutes are down a bit this season and he's been hit-or-miss with two single-digit scoring games through six contests, so he's just a borderline standard-league asset with limited upside.

Maybe it's his knee, but Favors has that look of a guy lacking explosiveness again. He does have two blocks in each of his last three games, so that's helped soften the blow of scoring just 9.8 points and 7.3 boards in his previous four. He may not be worth owning in shallower leagues with Jae Crowder getting a lot of run.

The Exum non-PG talk hasn't exactly come to fruition, but he's excelled in his role behind Ricky Rubio. Exum may not hold much fantasy value now, but that would likely change if anything happened to the starting perimeter guys.
It remains to be seen if this is related to his first half issue, but it likely is. We'll be sure to update as we know more.

Hes playing about three fewer minutes per game this season, and his steals are down from 1.7 in 2017-18 to 1.0 this season. Maybe he can get his steals back up because he averaged 1.5+ takeaways in three straight seasons, but his FT% (42.9) is way down as well. If you want to drop him for a hot free agent its not a bad idea since Young will likely just be a late-round guy.

It was definitely his time to shine with Anthony Davis (elbow) out and Julius Randle being neutralized by Rudy Gobert. Mirotic did also play some minutes as the lone big, so that could be in the cards if AD needs to miss more time -- it's not a serious injury. Mirotic has been on fire all year and looks like a fantasy steal.

Hes quietly having one of his best seasons yet with 9.0 points, 3.6 assists, 3.8 rebounds, 1.0 steals and 1.6 triples prior to Saturday. Tyreke Evans (personal) was out, so Joseph saw a season-high in minutes tonight. Darren Collison finally got back on track, so Joseph is still just a deep-league asset until further notice.

That's two good games in a row for Holiday following 26 points on Friday, and he had a little flash and flare on the offensive side today. There was never any need to panic after Holiday's slow start and he should be back on track as an early-round player.

An aggressive Myles Turner isnt as common these days, with this being only his third game out of six with double-digit shot attempts. Hopefully tonight gives him some confidence to keep firing away, because he has nowhere to go but up with one of the safest floors in fantasy  hes pretty much a lock for top-50 value because he can get you two blocks per night with excellent percentages. If this game was a little closer, this line could have been a lot better.

Collison had really been struggling, but this was the perfect storm with Tyreke Evans (personal) out and the Cavaliers ranking 28th in defensive efficiency. He cruised to a top-50 finish last season, so his owners just need to hang in there and hope that tonight is a sign of things to come.

He'll be seeing Rudy Gobert in his dreams tonight with Gobert keeping Randle away from easy paint points, and Gobert owned him when the Jazz had the rock. Randle looked healthy and there's been no concern about his plantar fascia, so expect him to be a full go this week. Anthony Davis should be back, as well.

He was behind Ian Clark in the rotation tonight with Elfrid Payton (ankle) hurt, but Jackson outplayed every Pelican guard not named Jrue Holiday. Jackson has looked terrific in a small sample in the preseason and in Vegas, so he could be a name to watch in super deep leagues.

He was the first forward off the bench as he came in for Julius Randle to push Nikola Mirotic to the five. Hill could see minutes close to 20 while Anthony Davis (elbow) recovers, but it doesn't sound like he'll be out long.

He was the first true big off the bench and looks to be ahead of Cheick Diallo. Still, the Pelicans pace is not Okafor's style, despite his mostly vegan diet. Assuming Anthony Davis (elbow) isn't out for long, leave him on the wire just about everywhere.

He picked up some extra rotation minutes with Elfrid Payton (ankle) getting hurt today. While Payton could not play for most of the second half, he was initially able to return after an ankle tweak in the first half. In other words, it doesn't sound serious, so Clark is only a speculative add in the deepest of leagues.
The Pelicans were blown out, so the 11 minutes are misleading due to garbage time. Jahlil Okafor is ahead of Diallo for now.

Not good. That's his bad knee and it keeps flaring up on him. Considering how long he's been dealing with this issue, it might make some sense for the Blazers to shut him down until he gets right. Jake Layman and Evan Turner could pick up some run, but there's not a fantasy pickup here.

It's the lowest scoring game with at least 20 minutes in his entire NBA career. Irving's dip in usage has been a trend all year, but only using seven possessions is a stunner tonight. Besides scoring, his stats are pretty much on par with the expectation, but Irving sitting at just 14.0 points per game is nowhere near even his biggest naysayers had him. He is a buy-low candidate, but the odds look to be against him in hitting early-round value this season.

His foot sprain clearly didn't bother him, but he did suffer a heel injury and didn't talk to the media. Theis was setting a lot of screens up high in the second unit, and his guards set him up with great looks all over the court. Aron Baynes (hamstring) could miss more time, but Theis is more of a deep-league target of a DFS punt. Garbage time helped him tonight, too.

Finally. Brown was a shell of himself on offense before today, and a hot start helped him carry the first unit offensively. With Jayson Tatum making a leap, there won't be many shots to go around in this offense and Brown has been subpar in percentages without really anything to hang his hat on in the box scores, so he's probably not worth holding in shallower leagues.

The Celtics have dealt with a disjointed offense at times, but their defense continues to bail them out as the best team in the league by far. As for Tatum, he finally didn't have it and the usage wasn't really there with Jaylen Brown getting hot early. There's obviously nothing to worry about as Tatum takes his offensive game to another level in his second season.

It was his most efficient shooting game from the floor, and it was encouraging to see coach Brad Stevens kept Hayward in there until the middle of the fourth with the Celtics up about 25 to get him close to his prescribed 25 minutes. The Celtics continue to get him around 25 minutes per game and there's no word that he'll have that limit elevated any time soon.

This was slightly aided by garbage time, but Rozier had a strong first half to help the Celtics pull away. The Boston second unit has been outstanding this year with Rozier being among the league leaders in defensive rating. Kyrie Irving just hasn't looked like himself, so maybe Rozier can find a path to more minutes. Plus, Boston blowing people out is good for his value.

As it turns, he wasn't going to shoot 65.2% from deep like he had in the first four. The Celtics defended Griffin tighter on the wing and it limited him from getting better looks off screens, and they also kept him from getting to the line with just four attempts. His 33.8 points per game was not sustainable, but Griffin could score in the upper 20s and should be in line for a big season under coach Dwane Casey.

Maybe this shoulder thing is bothering him. He's having a rough start to the year, but it's not like anyone else is stepping up while Bullock struggles. He should continue to see big minutes and the loss of Luke Kennard (shoulder) secures his role even more. That said, if you want to drop Bullock because of his poor play, it's not like people in your 12-team league are going to be dropping any decent FAAB or a high waiver on him.

It's the first time he failed to get a double-double and coach Dwane Casey may have kept Drummond in there in garbage time to avoid snapping his streak. Before tonight, Drummond was just a shade under 27% in total rebounding rate and he had 17.8 boards per game over the first four, so he'll likely rebound against Boston again on Tuesday.

Before today, things couldn't have gone much worse for Johnson in the first three, making just 30.4 percent from the field. Even in what has been his best game of the year in this bad loss, it's not like this will move the needle on him as a pickup in fantasy. If he has 2-3 more games like this in the next week, maybe Johnson can garner the attention of fantasy owners.
He was only in the locker room for a few minutes so hopefully he's fine going forward.
He took a nice shot from Gordon and was examined by the training staff. We'll update you as soon as we know more.

This is likely from his injury in the first half and it may have swelled up at half. In case you missed it, he slipped when he was guarding Ricky Rubio and had a fall after that. Payton was able to get back on offense and he did return, so it likely isn't serious. While he's out, we'll see more Ian Clark while Frank Jackson also got his first rotation minutes tonight. Payton finished with two rebounds, four assists and two turnovers in 16 minutes.
Coach Luke Walton likes the idea of splitting up LeBron and Rondo, which is great for Lonzo. Starting is great for his fantasy value, as it should earn him more playing time.
He went to the locker room and was stretching his leg on the bench after that, so it's likely another cramping issue for the second night in a row.

He did have a cramping issue yesterday and it could be that again. Payton was guarding Ricky Rubio had slipped on a step, and then he fell under the basket. He jogged slowly to get to the offensive side of the floor, then checked out and went to the locker room. If he can't return, we'll see more Ian Clark to play off the ball.

Embiid was a game-time decision after rolling his ankle in practice on Friday. He warmed up and got the go-ahead to be able to play. Coach Brett Brown was optimistic in his pregame press conference and also said he thought Embiid's X-rays were negative. There's no word on whether or not he'll be limited, but hopefully he can be effective either way.

He had a sleeve on his left leg and may have done some other on-court work before this game. Booker is only day-to-day after his Wednesday hammy pull and hopefully he can make it back out there next week. Josh Jackson should get the start and would see huge minutes while one of the rookie PGs gets some burn.

He was called probable for this shoulder issue, but he should be ready to roll for a full workload. With Luke Kennard out, Bullock should see extra minutes with plenty of treys, so he's worth a look in standard leagues.
He is not on coach Gregg Popovich's good side and it may take time for him to get the system down. Leave Poeltl on the wire.

He's started in the first four games of the season, so it's likely a matchup move against the up-tempo Lakers. Assuming the Spurs aren't up to something, Gay should still see minutes in the 24-28 range in a fantasy-friendly matchup

He's been moving in and out of the starting lineup, but Cunningham managed just three points in 29 minutes in his start on Monday. He's only a tourney DFS play in hopes he can rack up boards or make easy shots.

Bertans and Cunningham will be joined by Bryn Forbes, DeMar DeRozan, and LaMarcus Aldridge in the starting unit. Coach Gregg Popovich hasn't been shy with switching up his starting lineup so far this season and tonight is no exception with Rudy Gay moving to the bench. Bertans doesn't have much fantasy value, outside of 3-pointers, but makes for an interesting DFS punt tonight.

He was called probable from some ankle soreness, which he suffered in practice a week ago. Ayton didn't look hobbled against the Lakers on Wednesday with a 22-point gem, so expect him to be a full go as he makes a case for Rookie of the Year.

He suffered what looked to be a scary injury in Sacramento, but he won't need to miss a whole game here. Gasol may have this issue pop up down the line, but he gets a great matchup against the Suns with a less than 100% Deandre Ayton.
Kyle Anderson will remain in the starting lineup and Brooks will likely back him up given the lack of depth at forward today. Brooks won't get enough volume to roster in most fantasy formats.

He has been playing some power forward this season, so his return could push Kelly Olynyk back to the bench. Jones Jr. has shown flashes in the young season, but he's been foul prone and likely won't do enough to matter in most leagues.

It'll be his season debut from this nagging issue that has bothered him since the start of camp. Ellington may not have a clear path to big minutes because of Rodney McGruder's strong start, so leave him on the wire.

Randle was probable, but he has been probable before with his plantar fascia injury. With AD out, Randle should be asked to create offense out of the post, but the bad news is he gets Rudy Gobert down on the block. Still, he should see more run and could have an increased usage rate to up his ceiling in DFS.

Wow. Davis suffered the injury on Friday night and it didn't bother him until it flared up on him after the game. It is to his shooting elbow, so perhaps that is a factor in keeping AD out against one of the better teams in the West. The Pelicans play again in Denver, so consider The Brow questionable for that one. With him out, the Pelicans will move Julius Randle into the starting lineup next to Nikola Mirotic while Cheick Diallo or Jahlil Okafor could back them up.

Winslow had a setback to his hammy this week and it cost him more time, so the Heat will undoubtedly take it easy on him. With Rodney McGruder playing lights out, Winslow may not get to 20 minutes in his return.

He did not practice today due to the soreness in his shoulder, and the Thunder will not have a shootaround tomorrow. If he can't go , Dennis Schroder would likely start while Hamidou Diallo could see more run after an impressive week.

He did suffer a minor hand injury on Friday, but the team says it's rest in a back-to-back set. Devonte Graham could get his first chance at rotation minutes, or maybe Malik Monk slots in as a backup PG because he handles the ball for the second unit quite a bit. That makes it two games in a row for Love with his foot soreness. The Cavs are the only 0-5 team in the NBA and it may not be long before they start to tank it up. The Cavs aren't going to start Channing Frye again and maybe they even rest him. Neither Dekker or Frye are reliable fantasy plays unless you're looking for a tourney punt in DFS, but Larry Nance could benefit even though he's played center.

He's going on the court at around the time of this news to warmup for the game tonight, so we should get an update at around 6:30 EDT. No word on if he will suit up, but he has a good chance with Aron Baynes (hamstring) not out there for this one. Theis isn't worth owning in most leagues while Al Horford is healthy.

Coach Alvin Gentry said he won't know AD's availability for tonight until after warmups, so we likely won't have much time before the 7:00 EDT tip time. Davis did hurt his elbow last night, but it didn't start to flare up until after he left the arena. If he can't go, Julius Randle and Nikola Mirotic would get a few more minutes while Cheick Diallo could get into the rotation. There would be more shots for Jrue Holiday and basically the entire rotation, too.

He looked fine on Friday in 37 minutes against the Kings with 13 points and he picked up a tech for getting in Buddy Hield's face, so maybe this is the first day he's dealing with the illness. The Wizards are in Los Angeles for Sunday night against the Clippers, so he could be a game-time decision. If he can't go, Jeff Green and Kelly Oubre would get more run.
His ankle tweak from last weekend will now hold him out for at least a week. Kuruc had a terrific preseason, but it may be tough for him to get minutes now that Rondae Hollis-Jefferson is back.

With Lonzo Ball staying the starting lineup, it should be Rajon Rondo shifting to a bench role. Rondo is back after a three-game absence today and his minutes likely take a hit with this news, but the pace of the Lakers may be enough to buoy his value in some formats.

The Lakers played their best two games of the season as they earned a win in Phoenix and beating the Nuggets at Staples Center, so coach Luke Walton will carry that momentum even with Rajon Rondo returning from his suspension. Ball's defense was outstanding and his transition game fits the identity of the team. This is terrific news for his fantasy value and he should see minutes next to Rondo, as well.

The Pelicans put out an injury report earlier today, but they just added AD to this new one in the afternoon. Davis did finish his game on Friday and played 38 minutes, but he had his worst shooting game of the season with a 6-of-19 shooting line. If this shooting-elbow problem is still bothering him, maybe the Pelicans sit him in a back-to-back set. If he can't go, there will be plenty of shots to go around while Nikola Mirotic and Julius Randle have their minutes extended. We would likely see some Cheick Diallo, as well.

Mbah a Moute did not play against the Rockets on Friday due to the knee injury. He is averaging just 5.0 points and 1.8 rebounds in 15.3 minutes this season, so he should be left on waivers in all fantasy leagues. Montrezl Harrell has been on fire of late. Over the Clippers last three games, Harrell is averaging 19.7 points, 7.3 rebounds, 1.7 steals and 2.3 blocks in 24.9 minutes. He should see again plenty of playing time on Sunday if Mbah a Moute is ruled out. Mike Scott would also play increased minutes.

Johnson has been practicing with the team this week, but has not yet been cleared to make his season debut. JJ played through a nagging hernia injury in 2017-18, and it was partly responsible for his dip in production. He averaged 10.9 points and 4.8 rebounds and shot 30.8 percent on 3-pointers last season. Thus, it could be that Miami is erring on the side of caution and waiting until he is fully healed before allowing him to play in a game.

Westbrook missed the first two games of the season while recovering from knee surgery, but has looked healthy in each of OKC's last two contests. He tallied 13 points, 15 rebounds, eight assists and five turnovers in 32 minutes on Thursday night vs. Boston. It's unknown if Russ injured his shoulder in that game or in practice on Friday. Also, Donovan did not specify which shoulder Westbrook injured. If Russ is ruled out Sunday, Dennis Schroder would draw the start at PG and would be a popular DFS target.

Jackson has struggled mightily this season. Over the Suns last three games, Jackson is averaging 5.0 points, 1.7 rebounds, 2.3 assists and 3.0 turnovers, while shooting just 27.3 percent from the floor, 20 percent from 3-point territory and 33.3 percent from the free-throw line. He did average 15/5/2 in the 35 games he started last season, so hopefully, he snaps out of his slump on Saturday.

Anderson is expected to suit up on Saturday, but he has been inefficient and ineffective this season. He is currently averaging just 5.5 points and 3.5 rebounds in 21.5 minutes, while shooting a putrid 36.0 percent from the floor and 20 percent from downtown.

Ayton tweaked his ankle last week, but it has not been an issue for him. He tallied 22 points, 11 rebounds, three assists and three blocks on Wednesday. On the season, he is averaging 16.3 points (on 62.8 percent shooting), 10.8 boards and 3.8 assists. With Devin Booker (hamstring) sidelined on Saturday, Ayton should see even more touches on the offensive end and could post his highest usage rate of the season.

Payton was cramping up at the end of Friday's game vs. Brooklyn, but it is clearly just a minor issue. He will be ready to rock Saturday vs. the Jazz. Elf is off to an excellent start this season, averaging 14.5 points, 7.0 rebounds and 7.0 assists.

Miller injured his quad Friday night in the Pelicans victory over the Nets and was unable to return to the contest. On the season, he is averaging 3.8 points and 1.5 assists in 15.0 minutes. Wes Johnson and Solomon Hill should see an uptick in minutes with Miller sidelined.

Randle is dealing with plantar fasciitis in his left foot but it hasn't slowed him down. He scored 14 points with seven rebounds, three assists, one steal, two blocks and two turnovers in 23 minutes on Friday night. For the season, he is averaging 17.5 points, 8.5 rebounds, and a career-high 1.0 treys in 23.3 minutes.

Jones did not play Wednesday vs. the Knicks but is expected to return to action on Saturday. However, both Justise Winslow (sore right hamstring) and Wayne Ellington (ankle) are also probable for this contest. As a result, Jones will likely see his playing time reduced significantly going forward.

Assuming he does suit up, Saturday will be Ellington's season debut. In 2017-18, he set Miami's single-season record for 3-pointers made (227), which was also the most off the bench in NBA history. However, he'll have to compete for playing time with D Wade and Rodney McGruder, who has exceeded expectations early on. Justise Winslow (sore right hamstring) is also probable for Saturday's game.

Derrick Jones Jr., Wayne Ellington and Winslow all remain probable for Saturday's contest. Winslow has yet to make his 2018-19 debut. In 2017-18, he averaged 7.8 points, 5.4 rebounds, and 2.2 assists. He is not worth rostering in most fantasy formats.

Channing Frye started Thursday in place of Love on Thursday and tallied five points and four rebounds in 21 minutes. Larry Nance logged 28 minutes off the bench and finished with 11 points, six rebounds, five assists and three steals. Dekker did not play Thursday. He is averaging 5.0 points and 3.3 rebounds in 10.8 minutes over his four appearances this season.

Theis has appeared in four of the Celtics five games this season and is averaging 3.3 points and 2.3 rebounds in 10.5 minutes. Aron Baynes (hamstring) has already been ruled out, so the C's may be a bit shorthanded up front. If Theis is unable to play, Marcus Morris and Guerschon Yabusele would soak up additional minutes.

Coach Brad Stevens said the team is holding out Baynes just to be conservative. Baynes said he does not feel hamstring pain, stating: 'If it was playoff time there would be no doubt.' The Celtics next game is Tuesday in Boston, and it would appear Baynes has a good chance to suit up for that contest. Daniel Theis (foot) is questionable for Saturday. If he is unable to play, Guerschon Yabusele would likely see an uptick in minutes. Marcus Morris will also log additional playing time Saturday.

Payton needed to be attended to by trainers as he sat on the court in the fourth quarter on Friday night, but it seemed evident that it as only a cramp issue. Elfrid Payton scored 17 points with five rebounds, six assists and one 3-pointer in 31 minutes vs. the Nets and will look to continue the hot start to his season Saturday night.

Harris hasn't played since the season opener, but is headed in the right direction. 'He's doing well,' Carlisle said. 'He's getting better gradually every day. I don't know when he'll play. It might be sooner than I thought. I think Sunday is very doubtful, but I just don't know. The injury wasn't a serious injury. Hey, when you're 35, you know your body and you got to step back and get treatment for a while until you don't feel it anymore. That's what we went through with Harrison. I'm hopeful it's sooner than later.' Even when fully healthy, Harris is not on the fantasy radar.

The Wiz dropped to 1-4 on the season Friday night and tension appears to be building in the locker room. 'Weve got guys thats worried about whos getting shots. You should never worry about that,' said Wall. Brad Beal also had some harsh comments: 'Sometimes, we have our own agendas on the floor, whether its complaining about shots, complaining about playing time, complaining about whatever it may be.' Neither player mentioned Otto Porter by name, but coach Scott Brooks did, saying Porter 'cant worry about' his shots. Yikes. The Wizards next game is Sunday vs. the Clippers.

Love missed multiple preseason games due to lingering soreness in his left foot and then, after struggling through the first four games of the regular season, he was ruled out of Thursday's contest vs. Detroit. Channing Frye started Thursday and tallied five points and four rebounds in 21 minutes. Larry Nance logged 28 minutes off the bench and finished with 11 points, six rebounds, five assists and three steals. Nance is worth DFS consideration if Love is ruled out Saturday.

Bullock had a dud on Thursday night (five points on 2-of-10 shooting) but was averaging 16.5 points over his first two games of the year. It seems a slight shoulder injury may have been part of the reason. Nonetheless, With Luke Kennard (shoulder) sidelined and Stanley Johnson playing poorly, Bullock is locked into heavy minutes and should continue to provide value in deep leagues.

Smith tweaked his ankle in Wednesday's game vs. Atlanta and played with a noticeable limp in that contest. He was expected to suit up Friday vs. the Raptors but was ruled out. Smith warmed up prior to the game, but said his ankle didn't feel right. We'll consider him questionable for now, and should expect an update after Sunday morning's shootaround.

This was on the heels of a 23-point effort on Wednesday, so Hield is heating up. He's very efficient for a SG and was hitting 50.7 from the field prior to Friday, and he kept that trend going with 8-of-17 shots tonight. He has a shot at mid-round value this season, especially if he can get his steals up (he only has one through six games).

It was quite a night for Fox with some sound defense and several highlights which included a crossover that put Austin Rivers on skates. His turnovers and FT% haven't improved since his rookie season just yet, but his FG% has gone up considerably -- he hit 7-of-14 shots tonight and is now hitting 47.4% on the season compared to 41.2% as a rookie.

He finished four points away from his career-high (30), and this was his third career game with 20+ points. Bjelica added 12 rebounds to complete his double-double with three assists, one steal, one block and six triples in 36 minutes. He was worth owning before this explosion and is now sitting inside the top-25 for 9-category rankings. Temper your expectations though, as the Kings will eventually take a longer look at their younger guys.
He was actually playing pretty well before the injury, but he's never been a reliable fantasy contributor and his rest-of-season outlook is pretty bleak on such a young roster.

He played 27 minutes and closed this game alongside Kelly Oubre with Otto Porter struggling, hitting 5-of-8 shots and a pair of free throws. The Wizards are shorthanded right now and coach Scott Brooks has been using smaller lineups, so Green has seen a nice bump in value. He has played 24 or more minutes in four out of five games, but he's still just a deep-league asset for now.

With Otto Porter struggling again, coach Scott Brooks turned to Oubre and Jeff Green. Oubre added nine rebounds, two assists, one steal, one block and five 3-pointers, and he's now played 29 or more minutes in three straight with averages of 20.3 points, 6.3 rebounds and 3.7 triples in that span. Oubre's value could trend down if Porter figures things out or when Dwight Howard (back) returns, but he has to be owned right now.

He played 22 minutes and has now seen less than 25 minutes of action in three out of five games. Kelly Oubre had the hot hand with 22 points and has been impressive with three straight games of 17+ points, and coach Scott Brooks has been rolling with Jeff Green an awful lot too. Porter's value is too low to trade right now, so fantasy owners just have to hope that he turns things around soon.

The Wizards really like their small-ball lineup with Markieff Morris at the five, so Mahinmi isn't going to get much run even with Dwight Howard (back) out. He can be left on the wire pretty much everywhere.

This was his second game of the season with at least 39 minutes and his third with at least 35. This was Beal's first bad shooting performance of the season, as he hit just 6-of-19 shots after hitting 50.6% in his previous for games. He was a true-game time call tonight, so maybe the injury held him back a bit. He's a top-5 fantasy SG and should get back on track vs. the Clippers on Sunday.

It still wasn't enough though, as the Wizards imploded late and fell to 1-4 on the season. He came into tonight's game shooting 41.3% from the field and 68.4% from the line, but it was never a concern for him. 'It takes time. It is what it is. I know Im putting in all the work in and preparing myself for every game,' Wall said. 'Youre not going to make every shot. You just got to go there and be confident.' We'll see if Wall and the Wizards can get a result in Los Angeles vs. the Clippers on Sunday, but a lot of Washington fans are already panicking.

He's playing just above 17.0 minutes per game on the season and won't have consistent value while Brook Lopez is healthy. On a side note, it's nice to see Henson expanding his range, as he's now shooting 5-of-11 from beyond the arc on the season. This makes him even more intriguing if Lopez ever picked up an injury.

He played just 21 minutes because of the blowout, finishing with a +21 in his limited action. Even with this dud factored in, Bledsoe is cruising with top-35 value in standard leagues and comfortably beating his ADP.

The Wolves were in shambles and the Bucks built a 30-point lead entering the fourth quarter, so Giannis took an early seat after 23 minutes. His efficiency hasn't been the best so far in the young season, but his counting stats are off the charts once again, especially his rebounding -- he's posting a career-high 20.5 rebounding percentage, up from 14.1% last season. It's scary how good this guy could be.
He got some burn in garbage time with the game well out of reach. If Delly is on your fantasy team, you can log off until next season.

He cleaned up in garbage time with the Bucks up by 30 points entering the fourth quarter. Maker is comfortably behind Brook Lopez and John Henson and there's no indication that that will change any time soon. We're taking him off the injury report after a knee issue limited him for a couple weeks.

These are dark days for KAT's owners, and he didn't even touch the floor in the fourth with Minnesota trailing by 30. Outside of blocks and FT%, his numbers are way down across the board. His fantasy owners just need to hang in there and hope KAT's situation improves when Jimmy Butler is inevitably traded.

He became the 94th player to join the NBA's 1,000 blocks club in this win, and AD has the last two performances in the NBA of at least 18 points, 14 rebounds, four steals and five blocks because of course he does. Yeah, AD is scoring a bunch at 27.3 points per game with 13.3 boards to go with it, but his 3.8 blocks and 2.5 steals are what really separates him from the bunch. If you passed on AD and he stays healthy, it's going to sting all season when you look at his stat lines.

He missed all five of his 3-pointers and couldn't salvage his line with four assists and two rebounds. Teague, Karl-Anthony Towns, Jimmy Butler and Josh Okogie all had a +/- rating of -23 or worse, and they scored a combined 28 points. The Wolves are a mess right now, but Teague's owners shouldn't overreact.

It was only a matter of time before he busted out of his three-game slump to start the year. Holiday also hit a game-winning jumper to keep the Pelicans as the only undefeated team in the West. The Pelicans continue to push the pace and that will set up a lot of easy transition buckets for Holiday, so expect him to be a helpful contributor in FG%. If you bought low on him this week, well done.

He probably should've sat this one out, but as you know, that's not his thing. The trade rumors have started to intensify again, and coach Tom Thibodeau addressed them at the morning shootaround. 'You just got to do what's right,' Thibs said. 'To me, it's like, if something is a good deal and you think you're getting good value, you have to do what's right for the franchise.' A trade is more likely to go down when Marquese Chriss and Brandon Knight are eligible to be moved on Oct. 31, but you never know in the NBA.

He continues to just set up shop in the paint and he's meshed nicely with Anthony Davis, as well. Randle is dealing with a minor plantar fascia issue and he was probable today, so hopefully things don't get worse for him.

He did suffer what looks to be a minor leg injury at the end of the game, but  after the game he said it was just cramps. Payton has done well in this up-tempo offense and looks like a solid value from drafts.

Things were going about as well as they could have, but Russell had a careless turnover with 7.5 seconds left to give the Pelicans the ball back and allow Jrue Holiday to win the game on the next possession. Russell has been hot for two games in a row now, and coach Kenny Atkinson likely won't punish him for just a lapse of judgment. He's trending up after a slow start.

The efficiency was not there, but Jrue Holiday has held countless All-Star guards in check. LeVert continues to show his grasp of the offense, his usage rate remains high, and he's really grown as a distributor to go with his explosive scoring style. While he has taken a step back after those off-the-charts two games to start, LeVert is still on track to be one of the best values on draft day.

He has found the form that made him a fantasy star back in 2014-15. Green is churning out top-40 value in 9-category leagues right now because of his 3-pointers (3.0), steals (1.0) and blocks (1.2), all while leading the Raptors in net rating (+19.8). He was flying off the waiver wire last week, but he's more than likely long gone in competitive leagues.

The scoring wasn't there, but Allen had one of his better games of the season from a defensive standpoint. Plus, only two fouls against Anthony Davis while keeping AD in check overall. In fact, all 28 of Allen's minutes came against AD and The Brow made just 5-of-18 from the field. Plus, the dimes and steals are showing up for Allen, so he'll be just fine as a breakout candidate.

He hit 4-of-8 shots and a pair of free throws, but missed his two 3-point attempts. The Raptors were missing three guys tonight including OG Anunoby (personal), so we can't read too much into the spike in minutes -- he was averaging 20.6 minutes per game before Friday. He is second on the Raptors in net rating (+17.8) and will earn an expanded role if he keeps it up, so he's a decent stash at the end of standard-league rosters.

The Nets went super small for long stretches in this game and coach Kenny Atkinson isn't quite ready to take the limits off Hollis-Jefferson. It should happen in the near future, so his owners should be hanging in there in all formats.

He now has 10+ assists in four straight games for the first time in his career and has led the Raptors to their first 6-0 start in franchise history. He's cruising right now and has been the 7th best player in 9-category leagues. He'll draw a matchup with Eric Bledsoe and the Bucks on Monday.
The Nets went super small again as Napier got hot in the second half, but both D'Angelo Russell and Caris LeVert were back to close. Napier is going to be too inconsistent to own in most leagues.

Revenge game? In Sunday's win over the Rockets, Harrell said revenge wasn't a factor, but could've fooled us with this one and a 17-point gem on Sunday as the Clippers won both. For tonight, Harrell lived in the paint and cleaned up at the line, making 14-of-15 from the stripe. Harrell had 21 and five at the end of the third thanks to playing the final 17 minutes in the first half and just taking over to close the third. He may not start, but there's no way Harrell can remain on the waiver wire with now three straight outstanding games.

Foul trouble got him and the flow of the game kept him out. Shai Gilgeous-Alexander hasn't looked like a rookie on either end and he's already shown he can switch in the NBA's PNR-happy style, so Beverley may need a trade to revive his fantasy value.

He was back in the starting lineup to match up with DeAndre Jordan, one of the last few non-shooting bigs in the NBA. 'Dying,' J-Val said of centers who can't shoot. 'The big guy's dying.' For context, that's one of the reasons why J-Val has spent so much time trying to expand his range. J-Val is only averaging 20.3 minutes as a starter compared to 18.0 minutes as a reserve, so the starting designation doesn't change his value too much. He will likely be back on the bench for Monday's matchup vs. Brook Lopez and the Bucks, but then back in the first unit for Tuesday's game vs. Joel Embiid's 76ers.
Montrezl Harrell may not start, but it's abundantly clear he is the man. Drop Gortat, assuming you haven't already.

The three-guard lineups were out in force today. Gilgeous-Alexander has likely already has closed the gap on Pat Beverley, and finding minutes at the three adds to his floor in most matchups. It's still going to take some times before you're really excited about putting SGA in your lineup, but you're going to have to wait because there will be a long line to put a claim in on him if he's dropped.
Harrison Barnes was limited to 28 minutes, but should be over 30+ soon. DFS is an easy cut in deeper leagues and is probably looking at minutes in the teens going forward.

He was in there for the first half as coach Doc Rivers mixed it up. It was a surprise to see him in there as the Clippers went heavy with three-guard lineups. If Luc Mbah a Moute (knee) is out, maybe Milos will stay in the rotation, but this could've been about the matchup against the smaller Rockets lineups.

It wasn't pretty and he was scoreless in the first half, but Brunson did settle into his role down the stretch. He finished 3-of-11 from the field and turned the ball over twice. It doesn't sound like Dennis Smith Jr.'s ankle injury is serious and he was a late scratch tonight, so there's no need to grab Brunson in most leagues. When Dallas is healthy, the rookie is still behind both DSJ and J.J. Barea, but coach Rick Carlisle wanted to keep his second unit together tonight.

He looked like he would've easily hit 30 after he had 19 in the first half, but the Clippers ran away from the Rockets and they didn't need Williams down the stretch. Before the game, coach Doc Rivers said he wants Lou to drive more, so Williams could get back to his high-scoring ways we saw last season.

Some rust is to be expected after a lengthy absence, but Barnes was moving well and should be back over 30+ minutes in no time. He's been the Mavs primary go-to scorer the last two seasons and he doesn't think that will change with a stronger supporting cast around him. 'My job is to go out there and be aggressive offensively and defensively,' Barnes said. 'I pretty much am used to adapting, so I dont see my role changing too much.' Even with Luka Doncic around, Barnes has a clear path to mid-round value.

If you started CP3 in DFS, you were very badly burned like Will Ferrell's character in Austin Powers. The stats were on Paul's side with Harden out with a usage rate near 30 in his time without Harden on the floor in Houston, and his assist percentage was around 55%. Paul will have another chance to put up a big line against Damian Lillard and the Blazers on Oct. 30.

He was 5-of-10 from the field and has suddenly turned into Dirk Nowitzki from the line this season -- he hit 8-of-9 free throws and is now shooting 84.6% on the season (22-of-26). That would obliterate his previous career-high of 58%, so it might be a little foolish to expect this pace the rest of the way. He still deserves a ton of credit for turning things around in his age-30 season and he's been awesome for the Mavs so far.

He played the last six minutes of garbage time to boost his stats slightly. He's pretty much unaffected by the James Harden injury because Carter-Williams is functionally a wing in this rotation. Leave him on the wire in most leagues

The first unit came out flat and Gordon couldn't do anything in his minutes staggered away from Chris Paul, making 3-of-14 from the field. He'll get another chance to produce without James Harden (hamstring) in the mix, so expect a much better game on Tuesday.

People were actually worried that Doncic's offense wouldn't translate because he's not the greatest athlete, but he just dropped 22 points with the NBA's best defender in Kawhi Leonard guarding him. Doncic has now scored 19+ points in four out of five games, and it was a relief to see him knock down all four of his free throws tonight after shooting 61.9% from the line prior to Friday. He'll get the Jazz on Sunday in Dallas.

He probably likes garbage time more than Christmas with 10 points in the fourth. Green will have another chance to produce with James Harden (hamstring) out at least one more, but this 19-point game probably wouldn't have got your attention had it been a close contest.

Things were going well for the Knicks, then the fourth quarter happened when they were outscored 47-16. Ntilikina had some trouble on Steph Curry, but this was a win for Ntilikina's outlook. Before the game, coach David Fizdale explained himself on why he was starting Franky Smokes. 'I want to see him in a lot of different capacities and see which one fits best, which one he might impact winning the best at,' Fizdale said. He also said he doesn't want to put a cap on his guard and he's going to take his time. There will be some ups and downs for the raw French guard, but he could still be worth a look if you're looking for a mystery box to add to your roster.

That's more like it. Green was only shooting 37.9% from the field and 66.7% from the line prior to Friday, so it was nice to see improvement there (7-of-8 FGs, 2-of-2 FTs). His turnovers (4) are still an issue, but with Green you just have to take the good with the bad. He'll have another favorable matchup vs. the Nets on Sunday.

The Knicks were up in the early fourth, so this wasn't garbage time despite the 28-point loss. He only committed two fouls and didn't look out of place against the NBA's best team. The Knicks have said they wanted to get Robinson some time in the G League to get him going, but maybe they'll change course given his performance in a start. Odds are he will be a headache to own in the near future, so he's more of a stash in weekly leagues or if adding him now doesn't hurt you.

He's clearly the guy that has stepped in to Kevin Knox's role while the rookie recovers from an ankle injury. Coach David Fizdale's rotation is a complete mess right now, so it's tough to tell how long Dotson will be the guy. He's more of a deep-league pickup because he'll lose run when Knox returns next month.

He was in the mix to start at center over Mitchell Robinson, but it turns out he started next to him. Vonleh has played more center than power forward, and chances are he'll go back into that role the next time out. This is a very fluid situation, so most owners may want to steer clear until it's not so murky. He could emerge as a stash if the Knicks sell off players.

He hit just 6-of-18 shots and missed all four of his 3-pointers. He's been particularly bad from deep this season, hitting just 4-of-31 (12.9%) attempts through six games. The shot attempts are still there with at least 14 over his last four games, and it's just a matter of time before one of the NBA's best shooters gets back into a rhythm. There's some obvious buy-low appeal here.

Coach David Fizdale has compared Thomas to Draymond Green, so it's a fun coincidence that he came off the bench in this one. Thomas doesn't offer enough fantasy upside when the Knicks can suit up at least eight guys.

He was -16 in 18 minutes. His role hasn't really changed much since Kevin Knox (ankle) went down with Damyean Dotson firmly ahead of him right now. Hezonja should be dropped in most leagues and/or swapped for Dotson.

This game was tight entering the fourth, but KD blew the lid off the arena with 25 of his points in the quarter (a career-high for points in a quarter). There was a lot of attention on KD because the Knicks are making him their top priority in free agency next summer, and he obviously loves playing at MSG, calling it a 'playground with walls.' KD has said himself that he's not looking beyond 2018-19, so we won't read too much into any of the chatter.
